Thank you to all who took time to show me around Summerour and share your ideas with me. I am proud to represent such a vibrant community, where our diversity is what makes us strong. I look forward to seeing what the future holds for these talented students!

Before heading out, I met with student leaders from 6-8th grades, accompanied by some of their favorite teachers. We heard about the struggles students and teachers faced during remote learning, the return to in-person schooling, and the need to get students engaged again. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FBvn76oWYAAYHSK.jpg

As a former professor, of course I had to find my way back into the classroom. I visited with many students and learned all about the ESOL programming at this 70% Hispanic school, where the students and teachers alike take pride in their diversity. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FBvn4PQWUAwFoxn.jpg

Summerour Middle is home to a lively community garden which is maintained and enjoyed by the students. The food grown here is sustainably grown and provides nutritious supplements to the school cafeteria. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FBvn06IXIAQaYGG.jpg

Then, I met several of the hardworking cafeteria workers and custodial staff who make our public schools a clean, healthy, and happy place for our children. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FBvnxX8XoAUbigx.jpg

First, I met with the Hispanic Mentoring Program, which was started in 2019 to mentor Hispanic middle school students, helping with language acquisition, and addressing technology barriers. This phenomenal program is also planning to expand mentorship to younger students soon. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FBvntqPXMAISCbn.jpg

I was so impressed by the faculty, staff, and students I met this week at Summerour Middle School. The school provides a number of unique opportunities for students from all different backgrounds to get plugged in and be creative. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FBvnpX6XsAQC1qd.jpg

Our job as lawmakers is to make this possible by:
-Passing transformational water policies
-Working with our Tribes and Pueblos & Communities
-Investing in our water management agencies
-Investing in resilient infrastructure and
-Protecting our rivers.

As we look to the future and managing these river systems in a time of change we must:
ü§ùLeverage partnerships
‚öõÔ∏èInvest in science and technology
üö∞Modernize our infrastructure and operations, and
üë®‚Äçüëß‚ÄçüëßEnsure our communities are at the table and helping to drive decisions.

Climate change is here. And it is threatening the ability of our communities to bring water to our fields, to meet the needs of our Tribes and Pueblos, acequias, farmers and ranchers, and our rivers ‚Äì which depend on these life-giving waters.

Nowhere is this more visible than in New Mexico, where our communities have faced historic drought conditions at the same time our state has grappled with its highest number of emergency declarations due to flooding and wildfires this year.

But it is clear that what we are seeing today is part of a much larger trend of a changing climate‚Äîas temperatures are getting hotter, our snowpack is declining, and we are seeing fundamental changes in our hydrologic systems.

Our rivers have been gripped by drought across the West this year. But our communities are no strangers to water scarcity, as our Tribes and Pueblos have lived on these lands since time immemorial and our land grant and acequia communities have shared water across generations.

Addressing drought and water resilience in the West requires that we take #ClimateActionNow and make transformational investments in our communities and rivers. Here's why üëáhttps://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zQhaihovcv4&feature=youtu.be

I heard about this case first-hand in Alamosa last year. It is just one example of how Mexican and Spanish communities in Alamosa at the turn of the century fought to move our country closer toward our highest ideals of equality and opportunity for all.

The decision allowed kids to attend the school most convenient to them. 

For years prior, Mexican and Spanish American kids in Alamosa like young Miguel Maestas were required to attend the Mexican Preparatory School even if other schools were closer to their homes.

As #HispanicHeritageMonth comes to a close, I want to highlight Maestas vs George H. Shone ‚Äî a 1913 landmark school desegregation case in Colorado.
